pr_title: ISPN-10457 Convert bulk blocking stream operations to publisher

timeline.bodyText: I suggest nullableToStream, I find the repetition of flatMap in the call sites a bit confusing.
timeline.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText: I agree the naming could be better. I am not sure I like the nullable part. Maybe filterConverterToFlatMapFunction is more descriptive :D
replies.author: wburns
danberindei

replies.bodyText:
Thinking further about flatMap(), I'm not even sure flatMap() is the best Stream method to use to handle the null values. Because the stream values are actually entries, we can use NullCacheEntry, something like this:

This was my idea originally, but something prevented it a while back. My guess is this is probably fine now though. The only problem is that these methods are public, so I will have to make some new methods instead. I will mess with it a bit though.
And I agree that IterationFilter can be redone, but I figure that is a bit out of scope of this PR at this time.
replies.author: wburns

timeline.bodyText: IMO there's no need to avoid the allocation here, because it happens at most once per segment.
timeline.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText: I won't revert it now, but if this stage is not null there is a high chance that it will be complete as most of our listeners in this case will be complete.
replies.author: wburns

timeline.bodyText: This should never be necessary, only the main test thread should block on BEFORE_INVOCATION.
timeline.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText: Agreed, I normally just did this in the tests as more of a way to document that nothing should be blocking on these invocations for this test. It is harmless imo.
replies.author: wburns

replies.bodyText: I guess it's a problem with the CheckPoint API and the Mocks "extensions", it's not obvious which events the test is supposed to wait on and which events the mocks are supposed to block on. But IMO triggering extra events only makes it harder to understand.
replies.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText: Okay, I figured the ones triggered forever at the beginning was a clear sign that those events were not used in the test, but I guess not.
replies.author: wburns

timeline.bodyText: Same here, because that's how the Mocks methods all create mocks that trigger BEFORE/AFTER_INVOCATION and block on BEFORE/AFTER_RELEASE.
timeline.author: danberindei

timeline.bodyText:
Surefire won't run this test because it doesn't end in Test
Also, what exactly is non-blocking about this test compared to other cluster listener tests?
timeline.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText: Hrmm, not sure why this test is here. Guessing it was just something I was using it as a temporary class. I can remove it.
replies.author: wburns

timeline.author: danberindei

timeline.bodyText: Queue suggests that items are being removed from the front, but AFAICT it's only iterated, so I'd replace it with a List.
timeline.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText: tbh just Collection would work. I believe this originates from old DistributedStream code where I used a Queue and removed first elements at some point. This is no longer true though.
replies.author: wburns
